questions.question:
Which two sets of values are printed by this function and sub?
```vb
Function GetVitals(ID As Long, Age As Long, Optional Weight As Long) As String
    GetVitals="ID=" & ID &"Age=" & Age & "Weight=" & Weight
End Function
Sub ShowVitals()
    Dim ID As Long, Age As Long,Weight as Long
    Debug.Print GetVitals(ID:=5,Age:=20)
    Debug.Print GetVitals(ID:=6,Age:=25,Weight:=130)
End Sub
```
questions.explanation:
```
ID=5 Age = 20 Weight=
ID=6 Age = 25 Weight=130
```
```
ID=5 Age = 20 Weight=0
ID=6 Age = 25 Weight=130
```
```
ID=5 Age = 20 Weight=Null
ID=6 Age = 25 Weight=130
```
```
ID=5 Age = 20
ID=6 Age = 25 Weight=130
```

questions.question:

`Sub CalledSub(Surname, Age)`
What is the principal difference between a class and an object?
questions.answer: A class describes the design of an object. An object is an instance of that design.
correctAnswer: A class describes the design of an object. An object is an instance of that design.
options: There is no meaningful difference. The terms are used interchangeably.
A class declares an object's properties. An object completes the declaration by defining events and methods.
An object is a template for a class.
A class describes the design of an object. An object is an instance of that design.

questions.question:

```vb
MsgBox VarB(0)
End Sub
Sub ShowValue()
Call MySub(10, "First arg", 2, 3.1416)
End Sub
```

```vb
Total = WorksheetFunction.Sum(TestArray)
End Sub
```

```vb
SquareIt = Basis ^ 2
```

`Range("E3:312").Range("B3").Select`
Which variable name is valid in VBA?
questions.explanation:
[Reference link](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/vba/language/concepts/getting-started/visual-basic-naming-rules)
`Use the following rules when you name procedures, constants, variables, and arguments in a Visual Basic module: You must use a letter as the first character. You can't use a space, period (.), exclamation mark (!), or the characters @, &, $, # in the name. Name can't exceed 255 characters in length.`

questions.question: Which is a valid definition of a user-defined data type?

```vb
Type CBC
Name As String
Next As String
End Type
```
```vb
Type CBC
Name As String
_Next As String
End Type
```
```vb
Type CBC
Name As String
@Option As String
End Type
```
```vb
Type CBC
Name As String
%For As String
End Type
```

questions.question: What is one way to duplicate a user form from one project into a different project?
questions.explanation:
1. Save and close the project with the existing user form.
2. Click Insert > File.
3. Browse to the location of the existing project.
4. Right-click it and select the user-form you want to duplicate.
1. Open the existing user form in Desing Mode.
2. Right-click the form and select Copy.
3. Switch to the other project.
4. Right-click Module and select Paste.
1. In the Project Explorer, right-click the user form and select Copy.
2. Switch to the new project.
3. Right-click UserForms and select Paste.
1. Open the existing user form in Design Mode.
2. Click File > Export File.
3. Switch to the other project.
4. Click File > Import File.

questions.question: The recording of a macro in Word is likely to be an incomplete record of the user's actions. Why?
questions.answer: Word's Macro Recorder does not record actions that inlove the selection of text by pointing with the mouse pointer.
correctAnswer: Word's Macro Recorder does not record actions that inlove the selection of text by pointing with the mouse pointer.
options: Word's Macro Recorder does not record actions initiated by keyboard shortcuts.
Word's Macro Recorder does not support Find & Replace edits.
Word's Macro Recorder does not record actions initiated by clicking a button on the Ribbon's Developer tab.
Word's Macro Recorder does not record actions that inlove the selection of text by pointing with the mouse pointer.

questions.question: How do you add a user form to a VBA project?
questions.explanation:
1. Select the project in the Project window of the Visual Basic Editor
2. Click the Design Mode button and select Insert Mode
1. Select the project in the Project window of the Visual Basic Editor
2. Click the Toolbox button and select UserForm
1. Select the project in the Project window of the Visual Basic Editor
2. Right-click the Run menu and select Customize
1. Select the project in the Project window of the Visual Basic Editor
2. Click Insert > UserForm

questions.question: If VBA code declares FileCount as a constant rather than a variable, the code tends to run faster. Why is this?
questions.answer: The Const declaration specifies the most efficient type given the constant's value
correctAnswer: The Const declaration specifies the most efficient type given the constant's value
options: The scope of constants is limited to the procedure that declares them
Constants are declared at compile time, but variables are declared at run time
Once declared in a project, the value of a constant cannot be changed. There is no need to look up the current value of FileCount when it is a constant.
The Const declaration specifies the most efficient type given the constant's value

questions.question: A VBA project must declare four classes. How many class modules are needed?
questions.answer: as many as are required by the variable types that the objects return
correctAnswer: as many as are required by the variable types that the objects return
options: two (one for the properties and one for the methods)
one (each class is declared in the same module)
as many as are required by the variable types that the objects return

questions.question:
What does this code display?
```vb
Sub MakeErrors()
Dim Y As Variant, Z As Variant
On Error Resume Next
Y = 1 / 0
MsgBox "Y = " & Y
On Error GoTo 0
Z - (0 - 3) ^ 0.5
MsgBox "Z = " & Z
End Sub
```
questions.answer: Z = in a message box and then a subsequent error message
correctAnswer: Z = in a message box and then a subsequent error message
options: Z = in a message box and then a subsequent error message
Y = in a message box and then a subsequent error message

questions.question: The VBA code block shown in the following four options runs when UserForm1's CommandButton1 button is clicked. Which block of code leaves UserForm1 loaded but not visible until the FoundErrors function has checked it, and then enables processing to continue if no errors are found?
questions.explanation:
```vb
Private Sub CommandButton1_Click()
If FoundErrors(Me) Then _
Me.Show
End Sub
```
```vb
Private Sub CommandButton1_Click()
If Not FoundErrors(UserForm1) Then _
Unload UserForm1
End Sub
```
```vb
Private Sub CommandButton1_Click()
Me.Hide
Do While FoundErrors(Me)
Me.Show
Loop
End Sub
```
```vb
Private Sub CommandButton1_Click()
Do While FoundErrors(UserForm1)
UserForm1.show
Loop
End Sub
```
> The first requirement is to make UserForm1 loaded but not visible, therefore, we need Me.Hide, **Me** in here referring to UserForm1

questions.question:
Why does this code generate a "Subscript out of range" error?
```vb
Sub Example()
    Dim MyArr() As Variant
    ReDim MyArr(3, 4)
    'some code
    ReDim Preserve MyArr(4, 4)
End Sub
```
questions.answer: You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify `ReDim Preserve`.
correctAnswer: You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify `ReDim Preserve`.
options: Arrays cannot be resized more than once.
MyArr was originally declared with three "rows".
You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify `ReDim Preserve`.
The correct syntax is `ReDim Preserve MyArr(0 To 4, 0 To 4)`.

questions.question: Which subroutine declaration does not cause a compile error?
questions.answer: `Sub Called(Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`; `Sub Called(Optional Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`
correctAnswer: `Sub Called(Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`
`Sub Called(Optional Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`
options: `Sub Called(Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`
`Sub Called(ParamArray Vals() As Variant, Salary As Long)`
`Sub Called(Optional Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As Variant)`
`Sub Called(Salary As Long, ParamArray Vals() As String)`

questions.question: How can a user enter data on a worksheet or document, or switch windows, while UserForm1 is displayed on the screen?
questions.answer: Set the user from's `ShowModal` property to False.

options: Show the form with this statement: `UserForm1.Show vbModal`
Include this statement in the code: `UserForm1.Hwnd = False.`
Set the user from's `SpecialEffect` property to `frmShowModal`
Set the user from's `ShowModal` property to False.

questions.question: SubA passes MyVar to SubB. How can you ensure that MyVar has its original value when control returns to SubA?
questions.answer: Declare SubB as Sub SubB(ByVal MyVar).
correctAnswer: Declare SubB as Sub SubB(ByVal MyVar).
options: Declare SubB as Sub SubB(ByRef MyVar).
Declare SubB as Sub SubB(Static MyVar).
Declare SubB as Sub SubB(ByVal MyVar).

questions.question:
Arrays cannot be resized more than once.
```vb
Sub Example() Dim MyArr() As Variant ReDim MyArr(3, 4) 'some code ReDim Preserve MyArr(4, 4)
End Sub Sub Example() Dim MyArr() As Variant ReDim MyArr(3, 4) 'some code ReDim Preserve MyArr(4, 4) End Sub
```
questions.answer: You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify ReDim Preserve.
correctAnswer: You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify ReDim Preserve.
options: The correct syntax is ReDim Preserve MyArr(0 To 4, 0 To 4).
You can resize only the last dimension of an array when you specify ReDim Preserve.
MyArr was originally declared with three "rows."

questions.question: Which block of code ends with the variable i equal to 5 and the variable X equal to 10?
questions.explanation:
```vb
Do
X = X + 1
i = i + 1
Loop Until i < 5
End Sub
```
```vb
Sub Loopi()
Dim X As Integer, i As Integer
For i = 1 To 5
X = X + 1
Next I
End Sub
```
```vb
Sub Loopi()
Dim X As Integer, i As Integer
Do Until i < 5
X = X + 1
i = i + 1
Loop
End Sub
```
```vb
Sub Loopi()
Dim X As Integer, i As Integer
Do
X = X + 1
i = i + 1
Loop While i < 5
End Sub
```

```vb
    Assoc.Name = Cells(i,1)
    Assoc.Number = Cells(i,2)
    Associates.Add Assoc
Next i
```
